text.headline: Important Innovations of the Machine Learning
text.text: A timeline of important innovations that contributed to the growth and advancements of machine learning

media.caption: An Illustration of how the Turing test worked

text.headline: The Turing Test
text.text: A revolutionary test Invented by Alan Turing which raised an important question Do machines think? setting up the foundations for machine learning as a concept

media.caption: A photo showing Samuel Arthur playing with his self-learning machine

text.headline: Samuel’s Checkers‐Playing Program
text.text: Arthur Samuel developed one of the first self-learning programs—a checkers game that improved its performance through experience. It Marked the first practical demonstration that machines could learn from data, helping coin the term “machine learning.”

text.headline: The Perceptron
text.text: The perceptron invented by Frank Rosenblatt, was the first algorithm that could learn from data by adjusting weights automatically.Before the perceptron, AI was mostly symbolic (rules-based).The perceptron showed that a machine could learn decision boundaries by updating weights through training (a precursor to gradient-based methods).”

media.caption: An illustration showing how backpropagation works

text.headline: Backpropagation
text.text: David Rumelhart, Geoffrey Hinton, and Ronald Williams popularized the backpropagation algorithm for training multi-layer neural networks.It Enabled effective training of deep networks by efficiently minimizing error—pivotal for neural network resurgence.

media.caption: An illustration showing how Support Vector Machines work

text.headline: Support Vector Machines (SVMs)
text.text: Corinna Cortes and Vladimir Vapnik introduced SVMs, a powerful supervised learning algorithm based on margin maximization. It Became a robust and effective tool for classification and regression, widely used in the era of statistical machine learning.

text.headline: Deep Belief Networks (DBNs)
text.text: Geoffrey Hinton and colleagues demonstrated unsupervised pretraining of deep belief networks, revitalizing deep learning. It Sparked renewed interest in deep networks and led to breakthroughs in representation learning.

text.headline: Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs)
text.text: Ian Goodfellow introduced GANs, where two neural networks (generator & discriminator) compete to generate realistic data. Heavily increasing advancements in generative modeling, including photorealistic image generation and creative AI.

media.caption: A photo showing Lee Sedol going up against the program Alpha Go

text.headline: AlphaGo
text.text: DeepMind’s AlphaGo combined deep learning and reinforcement learning (plus tree search) to defeat Go champion Lee Sedol in a game of Go, demonstrating AI’s ability to master highly complex, strategic tasks.

text.headline: Generative Pre-trained Transformer 3 or GPT-3
text.text: OpenAI released GPT-3, a language model with 175 billion parameters capable of few-shot learning. Marking a leap in generative language models, powering versatile applications in text generation, coding, and conversational AI.

text.headline: Text-to-video (Sora)
text.text: High-fidelity, minute-long video generation marks rapid progress in multimodal generative models.
